I first knew the prisoner by the name of Rosetta White—I was present at the parish church at Clapham when she was married to Robert Daughters, my husband's cousin—I had attended the church the Sunday before, and heard them asked—Daughters was a single man, and was a carman, working in Tower-street—he had lodged in the parish of Clapham some time before—I only saw the prisoner about four times before she was married—the first time was about a month before—I think Mr. Murray was the clergyman that married them—I went and got the certificate from the church after they were married—the clerk gave it me—I examined it with the register at the parish church—I saw it written from the book—I saw them once afterwards at their door, in Kent-street, but did not go in—I saw Robert Daughters alive yesterday.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How came you to go to the church to get this? A. Daughters's mother asked me to go with her—she and Daugh
ters prosecute this case—I have known Daughters nine years—I have seen him a great number of times—I cannot say how many—I do not know where he was in 1839—he has been a soldier, and has been at different parts—I be
lieve he has not been to India—I do not know what regiment he was in—he is not in the same regiment now—he first turned soldier five years ago—he was a carman when they were married—I do not know how soon after the marriage he turned soldier—he was constantly absent—he has been to Leeds, and several other places, I believe—his wife did not go with him—I do not know where he was in July, 1841—I did not see him then—I went down to Chatham to tee him last year, in the depot—I cannot say how long he was there—I did not go to see him anywhere else—I cannot say whether he be
haved well to his wife—I do not know anything about her buying some fur
niture, and his selling it, and making use of it—I have heard it was the case, but her mother says it was not—I have heard of his behaving ill to her, from her mother, and then going away as a soldier—he is a soldier now—he went to Chatham yesterday.

MICHAEL GEORGE DREWITT . I am a lamp-lighter—the last witness is my wife. I was present when the prisoner was married to Robert Daughters, on the 16th of February—I knew both the parties—she went by the name of Rosetta White then.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell how soon he went for a soldier? A. No, I cannot—I signed my name, "George Drewitt," to the register.

WILLIAM ST. JOHN TURNER . I am parish clerk of the district church of St. Peter's, Walworth. I produce a copy of the register of marriage—I was present at the prisoner's marriage—she gave orders for the banns to be put up—I think I saw her twice or thrice on the subject—I made the extract from the register, and examined it—it is a true copy—(The extract stated that William Highwood, batchelor, and Rachael Smith, spinster, were married on the 11th July, 1841, by George Anslie, minister, in presence of H. Dove and W. S. Turner.)
Cross-examined. Q. Dove I suppose was a friend of the par ties? A.

Yes, I believe he is not here—I do not recollect all the young women that come to be married—the prisoner made her mark—I thought there was some
thing rather particular in her appearance when she came to put up the banns—I have been thirty-eight years in the neighbourhood, and she has been a great many years about the neighbourhood, and I have seen her many times—I knew her by sight, but not by name—I am quite sure she is the person—I did not know the man she was married to—he signed his name "High
wood," and was married in that name—whether his name was Highwood or not I do not know—I have not got the original book here in which he signed his name—I have a distinct recollection of his telling me that his name was Highwood—I invariably ask the parties their names, and how they spell them.

JOHN TROTT (police-constable M 193.) I apprehended the prisoner on the 10th of Nov.—I asked at the house where she was residing for Mrs. High
wood—she was brought to the door to me—I told her a person a little way up the street wanted to speak to her—she walked with me to where the first husband was standing—he walked towards her, and as soon as she saw him, she said, "I thought as much; I am living with a man; I am not married to him."
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months, without hard labour.

258.
THOMAS BELGER was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Nov., 7 panes of glass, value 3s., the goods of
George Wix, and fixed to a building.

GEORGE RUSSEN (police-constable V 266.)On the 13th of Nov. I was on duty on the Wandsworth-road, and near Vauxhall-gate, I saw the prisoner walking along the road, carrying a sack and something else in his hand—I stopped him, and it was glass, folded in the sack—I asked him where he had brought it from—he said from his master, Mr. Atfield, at Battersea—I saw wet putty on the edge, as if it had been just taken out, and said, "This glass has been just taken out of some place"—he said, "No, it has not, I bought it in a shop in Salmon-street, that is the truth of it"—I took him to the station, and he there said he had taken it out of a glass cupboard where he was living—I went to the house where he said he was living—there was no such a thing as a glass cupboard there, nor had there been—I went to Mr. Atfield, his master, and he had not taken it from there—I went to the shop where he said he had bought it, and they had no recollection of any person buying such a thing there, neither did they know it—I then found Mr. Wix, Prisoner. He has sworn quite false; when he asked me how I came by the glass, I said it belonged to myself; I had it in my hand, not in the sack; I told him I had it from my own home, that I had had it in my possession seven or eight weeks; I had taken it out of a cupboard which I burnt, not being worth the trouble of moving; the sack I borrowed of a labourer; we met another constable; he told me to try and get away, and said, "I will do what I can for you." Witness. I did not.

GEORGE WIX . I am building a house in Battersea-fields—I missed some panes of glass from some sashes there—I cannot identify the glass, but they fit the openings in the sashes, and some pieces of glass which were found on the wall on the premises fit two broken squares found on the prisoner—I noticed the pieces of glass on the wall before the policeman came, but I did not know what they were, and did not disturb them—these are the same number of panes I missed, and they are the same size and quality.
ROBERT COLLINS (police-constable V 108.) On the 14th of Nov. I went

to Mr. Wix's building in Battersea-fields—I picked up four pieces of glass three in the wash-house, and one about three feet from the window-cill—I matched them with two broken squares taken from the prisoner, and they exactly match.

Prisoner. He did not find them there—I told him I had broken the glass coming along, I heard him tell the other to go and find the pieces, and make it all right, and they winked and nodded to one another.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Three Months.

259.
WILLIAM APPLETON,
EDWARD CARRINGTON , and
JAMES NICHOLLS were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Robert Roger Phillips, on the 8th of Nov., putting him in fear, and taking from his person and against his will, 1 watch, value 30s., and 1 chain, 5s., his property; and immediately be
fore, at the time of, and after the said robbery, feloniously beating, striking, and using other personal violence towards him.

ROBERT ROGER PHILLIPS . I am a tailor, and live in Margaret-terrace, Westminster—about one o'clock on the morning of the 8th of Nov. I was returning from my sister-in-law's in William-place, William-street, Pitt-street, Old Kent-road, with my wife, my sister-in-law, and cousin Archibald Penny-cook—I saw a mob at the end of William-street fighting—we had to pass them, and could not do so without touching them—Pennycook was walking a-head of me, and was struck on the hat, I believe by Carrington, but I am not posi
tive—I came up within a foot of him—Appleton asked me what I wanted—I said I wanted to pass—I received a blow from him on the left side of the chest and fell—I rose again, and he struck me, and at the same time caught my watch-guard, which was hanging from my waistcoat-pocket, and ran away with it, watch and all—as I was pursuing him, I believe Carrington gave me a blow or a shove, and I went up against the wall—I did not fall down, but ran again, and was surrounded by the mob—I called "Police!" and "Stop thief!" as bard as I could—the policeman came—I told him I had been robbed of my watch and guard—I could not see Appleton at that time, but I saw Carrington, who was one of the party that shoved me as I was pur
suing Appleton, and I gave him in charge.

Cross-examined by Mr. CHARNOCK. Q. I suppose it was rather dark? A. There was a gaslight at the corner—I had come from St. Margaret's-ter
race to my sister-in-law's between eight and nine o'clock—I had no supper there—I had been drinking nothing to intoxicate me—I had had a drop of ale at my sister's—I cannot exactly say what I had drank—I had no spirits or beer the whole day—I was perfectly sober—I will not swear it was Carrington that struck Pennycook—he shoved against me as I was running from the corner of William's-place to the Kent-road—Carrington was running—there were about twenty people there—I should not say there were fifty.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. What sort of a night was this? A. I think it was rather darkish—the gas was just over our heads where I was struck—I did not get into the midst of the mob—I was standing by the side of them, wanting to pass to go home—I could not go through with out going against some one or other—immediately I came up I said I wanted to pass, and I had no sooner said it than I received a blow that knocked me down—there was no one but Appleton near enough to strike me at that time—I was trying to go through the mob without interfering with any one, but I could not—I know Appleton's features well—he came round the corner afterwards and asked me what was the matter, of his own accord; and I said

"That is the man that stole my watch," and gave him in charge—he came round quite as if he knew nothing of it—he had on, I think, a velvet waistcoat and a red handkerchief or comforter round his neck—he had no hat on—he ap
peared as if he had been chased—I should say he had run for about 100 yards—when I hallooed "Stop thief!" and "Policeman!" there was a regu
lar bustle all at once—he ran, and I ran ten or a dozen yards after him—I did not lose him till the mob surrounded me.

ARCHIBALD PENNYCOOK . I am a coach-maker, and live in St. Margaret's-terrace, Westminster. I was in the company of the prosecutor and his wife, going along the corner of William-street, about a quarter to one o'clock—there was a mob—when we got up to the people I heard some words, "Go it, Scotty," or something—I made a halt, because I could not pass without interfering—Appleton came and asked what I wanted—I said I wanted nothing—"Then," said he, "do you want to fight?"—I said, "No"—"What do you want?" said he—I said, "I want nothing but to pass"—he then left me on the left, and I received a blow on my hat, and, turning round, I observed Nicholls with his hand up, and down again on my hat, and so on followed the rest that were round me; as many as could get round me struck my hat—Phillips roared out "Police," and ran off calling "Police"—I leaped out from among them, and ran after him—I stopped at the head of the street—a policeman came up—Phillips told him he had had his watch taken from him—Carrington came and inquired what was the matter, and was given in charge—Appleton then came forward and made the same inquiry, and he was taken.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When you came up there was a fight going on? A. Yes, but I did not see it; I heard the words, "Go it, Scotty"—I had not spoken at all—I was near the centre of the crowd—they got me in among them—the blow Nicholls gave me was not when in the centre of the crowd—it was the second blow I received—I know nothing of his fighting.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. When did you receive the blow? A. As soon as I got to the edge of the mob—my back was towards them—I do not know whether they call it bonneting—it broke my hat, but it did not go over my eyes—Appleton did not strike me—I was not going into the mob—I did not see Appleton do anything.

ISABELLA HOOPER . I was in company with Phillips and Pennycook—my sister was there, but, from ill-usage, is not able to be here to-day—Penny
cook received a knock on his hat behind—I said to the person, "What do you knock the young man in that way for? what a shame"—he said, "What a shame!" in a jeering way, and went away—I do not know that person—I only saw one blow struck on his hat at that time—Phillips was just by his side, and was struck by Appleton, as I understood from my sister—his hat was knocked off—I went to pick it up, and some fellow tried to push me down—I took it up, gave it to my sister, and ran after Phillips—I had no bonnet or shawl on at that time, I had left them in the house—I only came out to see them to the corner, just through a little passage into the street—my sister was pushed and knocked about, which has brought on an illness.

JAMES WAUGH (police-constable M 220.) I was on duty at the Bricklayer's Arms—I ran into the Kent-road, and saw Phillips running and calling "Po
lice"—I went over to him, and asked what was the matter—he said he had lost his watch and chain—while he was talking, Carrington came up and I said to him, "What is this about?"—he said, "I do not know anything at all about it"—I said, "The man says you have assaulted him"—he said he had done nothing—during that time Appleton came up—the prosecutor said, "This is the man that took my watch and chain"—I called the assist
ance

of another constable, and took them to the station—while there Nicholls came in, and was identified as being one of the parties that had struck Penny
cook.

Cross-examined by MR. CROUCH. Q. You had Carrington in custody first? A. Yes—Appleton came up, in a minute or two afterwards, with fourteen or fifteen more, and was picked out—I cannot say that he saw me previous to his coming near me—he came up at the back of the coaches—he had no op
portunity of getting away—I called to him, and said, "I shall want you"—he went to the station willingly—when he was charged with the robbery he said he knew nothing at all about it—I bad seen the mob come out of the King's Arms there, and knew they had been there to what they call a Fifth of November supper, which they have had, to my knowledge, for the last ten years—I saw nothing of the fight—I heard of it afterwards—the prosecutor and his party appeared sober, but flurried—they did not appear to have been drinking—Appleton did not appear flurried, as if he had been chased—I searched them, but found nothing on them.
NOT GUILTY .

260.
JAMES NICHOLLS and
EDWARD CARRINGTON were again indicted for
assaulting
Archibald Pennycook, with intent to rob him.

ARCHIBALD PENNYCOOK . About one o'clock on the morning of the 8th of Nov., I was with Phillips and Isabella Hooper—there was a mob at the bottom of William-street—I went towards it—Appleton spoke to me, and after he left me I received a blow on the hat—I turned round, and saw Nicholls with his hand held up, which descended on my hat again—I re
ceived a blow from a person in the mob which broke the crown of my hat—I did not see Carrington do anything—nothing was done to my person or pro
perty to intimate that there was any desire to rob me.
ISABELLA HOOPER . I saw both the prisoners in the mob—I did not see them do anything.

ROBERT ROGER PHILLIPS . I believe that Carrington struck Pennycook, but I am not positive—I saw Nicholls strike him afterwards on his hat—my watch was stolen as soon as I received the blow from Appleton.
NOT GUILTY .

261.
MARY MACAULIFFE was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Nov., at Lambeth, 2 coats, value 4l. 10s.; 1 hat, 13s.; 2 pairs of boots, 1l. 1s.; 1 table-cloth, 1s.; 1 tea-pot, 2s.; 1 kettle, 10s.; 1 tea-caddy, 4s.; and 2 candlesticks, 2s.; the goods of
Joseph Kendall, in his dwelling-house; and afterwards, about eight o'clock in the night of the same day, burglariously breaking out of the said dwelling-house

SOPHIA KENDALL . I am the wife of Joseph Kendall, of Agar-cottage, Sid
ney-place, Clapham-road, in the parish of Lambeth. The prisoner came into our service on the 5th of May, and left on the Monday following—on the 14th of Nov., a little after seven o'clock in the morning, I missed the articles stated, which I had seen safe on Sunday night—when I went down in the morning three doors were open, which had been fastened over night—they had been opened from within—the prisoner was not living with me at this time—I had not seen her on the Sunday—I do not know how she got there—I made the house fast over night, at a little after nine o'clock—I am sure it was after nine—every thing was safe—I cannot say that I particularly observed these articles after nine o'clock—I was in the kitchen, and did not miss anything.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES (police-constable M 127.) On the 14th of Nov., about half-past six o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoner coining out of the Alfred's Head at the corner of the London-road, which is about two miles and a half from the prosecutor's—she had a bundle—I stopped her, and

found it contained two coats and two pairs of boots—she said the was going to Whitechapel—I asked what she had there—she said, "Two coats"—I asked where she came from—she said, "From Camberwell"—I asked her how far she had come from the wagon that she came out of—she said, "Only from the Horns"—I asked her if she had been moving—she said, "Yes"—I said it was very early—she said she bad a long way to go, and thought she would have the day before her—she said they were her husband's coats—she was going to have them altered—I asked what alteration they wanted—she said her husband had not left her any thing, and she was going to make what she could of them—I took her to the station—she gave the name of "Mrs. Newnham, Camberwell-grove," as the place she had moved from—I went there, but could not find any such person—I had seen her packing up some things in a washing-tub in the Alfred's Head—I went there, and found a tea
caddy, a tea-kettle, a tea-pot, a pair of metal candlesticks, a table-cloth, and a hat tied up in a handkerchief.

ALFRED SPICE (police-constable V 41.) On the morning of the 14th, about half-past five or twenty minutes to six o'clock, I saw a wagon in the Clap
ham-road—when it stopped, a basket of apples fell, and the prisoner stepped off the path and picked them up—it was going towards town, in a direction from the prosecutor's house, and about a quarter of a mile from it—I saw a washing-tub on the rods of the wagon, but none of the rest of the property—I have not seen the washing-tub which the officer saw—it is not here—I asked the prisoner whether she was moving—she said from No. 50, Lark-hall-lane—I said there was no such number there—she said there was about half-way up the lane—I asked what the name of the place was—she said, "No particular name, Larkhall-lane."
Prisoner. I hope you will be merciful to me.
GUILTY . Aged 28.

262.
MARY MACAULIFFE was again indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of Sept., 1 gown, value 1l.; 6 knives, 1s.; 6 forks, 1s.; and 20 paintings and frames, the goods of
Mary Ann Pitman, her mistress.

MARY ANN PITMAN . I am a widow, and life at No. 60, Walcot-place, Lambeth. The prisoner was in my service for three weeks—she left on the 6th of Oct.—I missed a quantity of pictures from a closet in the kitchen after she was gone—the policeman brought them afterwards—the closet was opened one day for the carpenter to ease the door, while the prisoner was there—I locked it afterwards—I cannot swear to the knives and forks—I lost some, and these look like mine—this dress is my sister's, and was kept in a wardrobe in the room in which the prisoner slept.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES (police-constable M 127.) I took the prisoner into custody on another charge—she was searched at the station, and eight du
plicates were found on her, which led to the discovery of this gown at Mr. Wharton's, Mount-street, Lambeth, and some knives and forks, and the pic
tures at Mr. Dempster's, the pawnbroker's—he is not hero—he gave the pro
perty up before the Magistrate—I afterwards went to the different pawn
brokers with the duplicates, and got these articles—I have not got the coun
terparts of the duplicates here.

ANN STEPHENS . I am the wife of Peter Stephens, a policeman—I am em
ployed at the Southwark-bridge station-house to search females—I searched the prisoner, and found eight duplicates on her, and delivered them to the officer.
(Property produced and sworn to,)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Ten Years.

263.
ROBERT HOULDER was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 31st of Oct., a forged request for the delivery of 6 pairs of Blucher boots;—
also, on same day, a forged request for the delivery of 2 pairs of Clarence boots, with intent to defraud
Henry Bonham;—
also, on the 19th of Nov., a forged request for the delivery of 4 pairs of boots, with intent to defraud
William Ager;to all of which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Ten Years.

264.
DANIEL BECKHAM was indicted
for feloniously forging and utter
ing an acceptance to a bill of exchange for 163l. 13s. 9d., with intent to de
fraud
Thomas Finnimore Evans and others.
MR. CLARKSON, on the part of the prosecution, offered no evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

265.
ELLEN MILLGATE was indicted
for the wilful murder of a new
born male child.

MARY FRYER . I live with Mr. Pimlott, my brother-in-law, at Camden-place, Camberwell. The prisoner was servant there—on Friday evening, the 21st of October, about half-past eight o'clock, I went up stairs to take her some gruel, and found her lyng on the bed, with some of the clothes on her, and her own clothes on—she had complained of pain in her stomach before that—I told her she had better undress, and get into bed—see did so—I stopped till she was in bed, and saw blood on her clothes—I said, "Ellen, you are unwell," which is a term females use—she said she was—I said, "You appear to be a great deal so"—she said, yes, she was—I then went down into the parlour, to my sister, and told her what I had seen—Mrs. Long the charwoman, came in—I went up afterwards, but know nothing more—I did not see her after eleven o'clock—I saw her again next morning in bed, and took up a band-box, which was on another box in her bed-room—the band
box felt very heavy—I said, "Ellen, what have you got in this box? stones, or what?"—she said, "I have got gowns and petticoats"—I took off the lid, took out a straw bonnet, and under that thought I saw something like a human body—my sister came into the room, and told Mrs. Long to examine it, and I went from it—I saw her take out the body of a male child—my sister said, "Oh, Ellen, how could you do such a thing as that?"—I did not hear any reply—I did not see her boxes examined, and saw no baby linen found—she was first taken ill about four or five o'clock—she had done her work up to that time—I had observed nothing to induce me to think her in the family way.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had she been long in the service of your brother-in-law? A. She came on the 17th of that month—she continued ill till she left on Saturday—I never attended a person in her situ
ation—my brother-in-law and sister engaged her in consequence of what they observed of her conduct in another service—she appeared a very respectable young woman—she came at their suggestion.

ANN LONG . I am a charwoman. On this Friday evening I went to Mr. Pimlott's house, and went up to the prisoner about ten o'clock in the evening, and found her in bed—I had never seen her before—I asked how she was—she said she was better—I asked how long before she had been unwell—she said two months when she was all right—I observed spots on the floor, and under the carpet, and said I thought it was longer than two months—I have had twelve children myself, and from what I observed I thought there

was a new-born baby—I went down to Mrs. Pimlott—I sat up all night, and went to and fro to her, but was not constantly with her—next morning I assisted in shifting her clothes—Mrs. Fryer took up a band-box, and said, "What have you got? stones, or what?"—I think she said gowns and petti
coats—Mrs. Fryer took the lid off, and Mrs. Pimlott said, "Mrs. Long, go and examine that box"—I found a male child dead in it—I thought it had been born a few hours, but it might be twelve—it had not been washed—I saw no marks of violence on it—there was what appeared a dark ribbon round its neck—I cannot say how it was fastened—I did not examine it—Mr. Green, the surgeon, came shortly—the lips were black, and the right side of the face very flat—the after-birth was attached to the child—Mrs. Pimlott said, "Oh, Ellen, how could you ever think to do so?" or something—she made no remark—the child was cold.

THOMAS JOSEPH GREEN . I am a surgeon, and live at Camberwell. I went on Friday evening, at ten o'clock, to Mr. Pimlott's, and saw the prisoner in bed—I asked how she felt—she said, better—I asked the cause of some blood on the floor, which had been pointed out—she said she had been unwell, and it was two or three months since she had been so before—I said it was unusual to lose so much on being unwell suddenly—she said * * * * * * I requested her to show me her breast, which being very dark round the nipple, with the enlargement of some glands, and the appearance of milk on pressure, I told her I felt sure she had been pregnant—nothing more passed that night—I imagined at, that rime that it was an early stage of pregnancy, and that she had miscarried—I gave directions for her treatment, and went away—next morning, at ten o'clock, I was sent for, and went into her room—she was still in bed—I was shown a bundle, which was placed on the floor, and opened—it was a full-grown male—its countenance was distorted—the pupil of the eye dilated, the mouth slightly open—the tongue; protruded, the hands were clenched, and the neck had round it what appeared to be a green ribbon, tied round more than once in a knot—it was tight—the navel string was un
divided—the precenta and membranes attached to the other extremity of it—I asked her how long the child had been born before the after-birth followed—she said about five minutes—I examined her person, and found she had been retently delivered of a child—I examined the child on Sunday morning, the 23rd of October—(The witness here entered into a more minute detail of the circumstances, and, upon his cross-examination, stated that he was unable positively to depose that the birth had been complete before life was extinct, and that the ribbon might have been put round the neck in the agony of labour, she being at the time in a state of unconsciousness.

GUILTY of Concealment. —
Confined Two Years.

266.
FREDERICK HENRY RIX was indicted
for a misdemeanor; to which he pleaded

267.
WILLIAM PURDUE was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of Oct, 23 half-crowns, 22 shillings, and 2 farthings; the monies of
Joseph Steel, his master.

JOHN GAMBLE . I am master of the National School at Mortlake. On the 2nd of Nov. I had a little boy in the school named James Benham searched for a whistle—the boy who searched him took a purse from his pocket containing 3l. 19s. 6d. in silver, and two farthings—I kept Benham and the prisoner back after the rest of the boys were discharged—I then asked Benham
where he obtained the money—he said of Purdue, and on questioning Purdue, he said he had taken it from Mr. Steel's till at different times.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Before be told you that, what did you say to him? A. Merely asked him where he had obtained the money—I certainly did not make him any promise or threat, nor was he caned.

COURT. Q. Did he say any thing else? A. Nothing more was said to him till he was examined in the presence of Mr. Steel, and then he again said he had taken it from Mr. Steel's till—I delivered the purse to Mr. Steel, and he gave the same purse back to me next morning—I delivered it into the hands of the officer.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How soon did you take him to Mr. Steel's? A. Perhaps about three hours—he had left school, and I believe went home—his mother lives close by, and I believe is a decent woman—I do not recollect that Mr. Steel told him in my presence that he entirely for-gave him—I will not swear it did take place—to the best of my knowledge it did not—the boy wrote down something on a piece of paper—I do not re
collect whether I said I must mention it to the clergyman—it is likely enough—probably, I did say that I must tell "the parson" of it, for fear I should lose my place—I do not remember it—I caused information to be conveyed to the clergyman.

Q. And was it in consequence of that, that this boy was taken up after Mr. Steel had forgiven him? A. I may say yes—I do not recollect whether Mr. Steel said in the presence of several persons that he entirely forgave him—I was these all the time, and I recollect nothing of the kind—it might take place, and I not recollect it, from the agitation arising from the discovery of such a theft—I heard Mr. Steel tell him to go home and make out a state
ment of what he took and what he spent, and the prisoner brought the state
ment to me—I have kept the statement—I sent the officer to the minister—I think the prisoner was taken up on the 3rd—both him and Benham were taken at first—the Magistrate took bail for the prisoner's appearance—he has been several years in the school.

JOSEPH STEEL . I am a grocer, and live at Mortlake—the prisoner lived with me as errand-boy—in consequence of receiving information from Mr. Gamble I sent for the prisoner—he came at once—Mr. Gamble questioned him in my presence respecting a purse of money which was found, and before any threat or promise was made the boy said he had taken it from my till—he had lived with me the last time for a month constantly—I knew him before I employed him, and had every reason to be satisfied with him—when he admitted taking the money, I again questioned him, and asked if he had not received it for any bills—he stated he had not, but he took it from the till at various times—I said unless he confessed the whole truth I would send for a policeman, as I thought he had accomplices, and I was willing to forgive him, as I thought him an honest boy—I desired him as well as Mr. Gamble to write it down, but previous to his leaving me I considered I had entirely forgiven him—I intended not to prosecute—I thought him penitent, and intended not to bring him before a court of justice—I thought by pardoning him I should do him more good—I did it from a feeling of humanity more than any thing else—I have no knowledge of this purse, and cannot swear to the money.

Cross-examined. Q. You told him you forgave him? A. Yes, Sir, I believe so—he went away, and was to put down the whole particulars on paper—I certainly never intended to proceed against him—I thought this money was the amount of some bills, as I thought it was impossible be could have taken it out of the till—Mr. Gamble was not there all the time—the paper that the boy wrote out was shown to mo by Mr. Gamble, but I cannot say

when—I was very much annoyed at being sent for by the Magistrate—they told me I was compromising a felony—I told the prisoner I would forgive him in the afternoon when he was brought to me—I really do not remember whe
ther I said I would forgive him before he said he took it—I said I would for
give him, and told him to pray to God to forgive him.

JAMES BENHAM . I am nearly thirteen years old. As I was going to school on Monday, the 31st of October, I saw the prisoner—he gave me some money in a purse—there were some half-crowns and shillings—he asked me to mind it till he went to Mr. Steel's, because it was a bill—my schoolmaster had me searched, and it was found.
Cross-examined. Q. You had been "whistling" in school, I suppose? A. Yes, Sir.

JAMES FINLAYSON (police-sergtant V 13.) I received information, and waited on Captain Page—he desired me to take the witness Benham and the prisoner into custody—I received this purse and money from Mr. Gamble—here are twenty-three half-crowns, twenty-two shillings, and two farthings.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you wait on anybody else? A. Yes, on Mr. Eades, the minister, and then on Captain Page—I did not know that Mr. Steel had forgiven the prisoner—I heard he would not prosecute him.
JURY to JOSEPH STEEL. Q. Was the till open to the prisoner I A. Yes; he was in the habit of serving and taking pence at times, and he has been in the shop alone.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 13.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor.

div1.p:
268.
MICHAEL DONOVAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Oct., 8 handkerschiefs, value 7d., the goods of
Margaret Susannah Truefit.

MARGARET SUSANNAH TRUEFIT . I live in Rotherhithe. These handker
schief are mine—they were safe at ten o'clock on Friday morning, the 28th of Oct., hanging for sale inside my door-post, pinned to a line—I did not miss them till I found them in possession of the policeman—the ticket was then taken off them.

GEORGE REDMAN (police-constable M 198.) I produce three handker
schiefs, which I found on the prisoner at twelve o'clock in the day, on the 28th of Oct.—he told me a sailor gave them to him—there were two more with the prisoner—I saw him watching different houses.

Prisoner's Defence. At half-past eleven o'clock I was at Dock-head, and met a sailor boy I had been sailing with before; he said, if I would go down to Deptford he would give me a little money; I went on with him, and the lad produced this handkerchief, and was going to chuck it away—I said, "What are you going to do with it?"—he said I might have it, and he gave

GUILTY .** Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

269.
GEORGE WILSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Nov., 16 yards of satin, value 4l. 16s., the goods of
Thomas Brooks and another, his masters;to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

270.
HENRY HIGHSTEAD was indicted
for stealing, en the 9th of Nov., 2 half-crowns, and one 6d.; the monies of
Charles Manners, his master, and that he had been befere convicted of felony;to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Transported for Seven Years—Convict Ship.

271.
CHARLES PEARSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of Nov., 1 till, value 6d.; 13 keys, 6d.; 1 penknife, 6d.; 1 purse, 2d.; 4 weights, 6d.; 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, 4 sixpences, 2 groats, 1 twopence, 57 pence, 134 halfpence, and 370 farthings; the goods of
William Sandwell; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

272.
JOHN DAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Nov., 1/2 lb. of black lead, value 2s.; the goods of
Cyrus Harris and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

273.
CHARLES BERRY was indicted
for embezzlement.

THOMAS GREEN . I keep the Jacob's-well, Upper ground-street—the prisoner was my pot-boy, and received money for me—on the 9tb of Nov. he asked me to lend him 1s., which I did—he afterwards came for some beer, and said he was going to take it to the stable for some man—he took it to the stable—I never saw him again till he was in custody—he never paid me any money from Miss James—he ought to have brought 15s. 4d.
MATILDA JAMES . I live with my father—on the 9th of Nov. I gave the prisoner a sovereign to pay Mr. Green 15s. 4 1/2 d.—I did not see him after—I told him to bring me a receipt, and he did not.
WILLIAM ROMAINE (police-constable L 38.) I took the prisoner—he said he did not know the Jacob's-well, and never lived there.
Prisoner. I never received a farthing of him all the time I was with him—he did not give me sufficient victuals, and I thought it was time to leave.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

274.
JAMES GARDINER was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Nov., 3/4 of a pint of gin, value 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Frazer Wilkins, his master, and that he had been before convicted of felony.

THOMAS FRAZER WILKINS . I keep the Rose and Crown public-house, Southwark—the prisoner had been in my service three weeks—he slept in a room below me—about six o'clock in the morning of the 1st of Nov. he came down stairs, I was on the watch, and followed him down—he opened one of the doors, and some one gave him in a stone jug—he came to the foun
tains in the bar, drew some gin in it, and went outside with it—I went to the door, and saw him offering it to a man that stood there—the man said some
thing, and he was bringing the jug back again—I stood in the way, and said, "What are you going to do with that?"—he said, "To draw the watchman a quartern of gin"—I said, "You know you ought not to do that, and you could not be going to do that, because you have got some gin in it, that you have just drawn"—he said he did not know it was wrong, he would not do it again—he said, "I will give him the jug back"—he was going away with the jug—I said, "Stop, you have got some gin in it."

Prisoner. I had opened the house—I said the watchman asked me for some gin which I drew him, and had got the money to pay for it. Witness. He had no right to draw any gin, and he offered me double the money for it.
PATRICK M'CORMACK (police-constable M 27.) I received charge of the prisoner, and the jug containing gin—the prisoner begged to be allowed to pay for it.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not receive the money for the gin laying on the counter? A. Yes.

Prisoner's Defence. I opened the house—the watchman came, and said, "Draw three quartens of gin," which I did, and took it out—the watchman was talking to two or three policemen—as I came back my master asked what I had—I said some gin that I drew for the watchman—the watchman said he did not ask for it—he had put the money in my hand.
JAMES GIFFORD (police-constable H 169.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

275.
WILLIAM SNOWSWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of Nov., 20lbs. of coals, value 3d.; the goods of
Stephen Finney, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames.

HENRY JOSEPH KING (Thames police-constable.) On the 29th of Nov. I saw the prisoner row his boat alongside the barge Emma, and get on the gun
wale, and throw some pieces of coal in them—he went again, sat on the gun
wale a quarter of an hour, and threw some more coals into his boat.
JOHN HOWES . I am a lighterman, of the Emma, in the employ of Joseph Finney—I only knaw his name by what the lighterman say.
NOT GUILTY .

276.
ROBERT BARFOOT and
MARY BARFOOT were indicted for
a misdemeanor.

JOSEPH MOUNT (police-constable C 115.) At half-past seven in the even
ing of the 2nd of Nov. I and Russell saw the prisoners and two others in Oxford-street—I watched them down to Charing-cross, and took them in Vine-street—I found no coin on these prisoners—they were remanded till the following Thursday, and then the other two were discharged, and the prisoners kept in custody—I went to a house, No. 122, Cornwall-road, Lam
beth—I saw the landlady of the house, Elizabeth Thorn, and her husband—he conducted us to a room in that house—he opened the door—I searched and found under the hob these five counterfeit shillings.

WILLIAM RUSSELL (police-constable C 113.) I was with Mount, and went to search the room—I found a pipkin, and some metal in it on a cup
board, and some plaster of Paris—there was no one in the room then but the landlord—the prisoners were in custody.

ELIZABETH THORN . I live in No. 121, Cornwall-road—I let the back room first floor of No. 122, to the prisoner, Mary—she lived there eight weeks—she said her husband was a tailor—the officer went into that room.

ROBERT THOMAS . While Mary was lodging at No. 122, Robert used to come there as her husband—I conducted the officers to that room—I saw them find five bad shillings under the hob, and this pipkin and plaster.

Robert Barfoot. Q. When did you see me? A. Repeatedly—on my being brought to Marborough-street, you were sitting down, and I could not posi
tively swear to you, but when you turned round I knew you.

MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These 5 shillings are all counterfeit, and all cast in one mould, not finished and have not been circulated—this metal is of a similar kind to that the counterfeit money it made of.
Robert Barfoot's Defence. I was never near, the room—Thorne stated very different at the office to what he has now.
Mary Barfoot's Defence. The lock of the door was not quite sound; any thing might have been put in the room.

ROBERT BARFOOT—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

MARY BARFOOT—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

277.
CHARLES MALES was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Dec., 12 pence, and 15 halfpence, the monies of
Charles Walter Travers and an
other, his masters; to which he pleaded

278.
WILLIAM GARRATT was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of Nov., 1 sachrometer and case, value 3l.; the goods of
John Perry.

JOHN PERRY . I am a brewer, and live in St. George's-road, Southwark. This is my sachrometer—I saw it safe on Monday the 21st of Nov., and it was missed on the Monday following—the prisoner had been in my service, but was discharged on the 11th of June last.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Have you a great many other servants? A. Yes—he was discharged for drunkenness—I had no charge against him for dishonesty.
BENJAMIN HAZLEBY . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this sachrometer of the prisoner, on the 25th of Nov., about six o'clock in the evening.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know him before? A. Not to my know
ledge—my masters's shop is in the Lower-road; Deptford—that is rather a populous neighbourhood—it was candle light—there were other customers in the shop, but I do not know that I should know any of them again—I was the only person serving.
COURT. Q. Are you sure he is the man that pawned this? A. Quite sure.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined Four Months.

279.
THOMAS HAYES was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

SUSAN WINDSOR . I am the wife of William Windsor, of Aldridge-street, Bermondsey New-road. Between five and six o'clock in the evening, of the 1st of December, I went down into the front room found the window open, and the prisoner concealed behind a chair under the window—my sister seized him, and he was given in charge.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been to the hospital to see my sister, and was going home; two men gave me a push, and something I had went over to their house; I knocked at the door, no one came, and I went to the window; I did not know whether the house was empty or not; I went in, then the lodger came home, and they came down and laughed at me.
Witness. He was crouching down concealing himself behind a chair.

GUILTY .* Aged 16.
Confined Nine Months.

280.
JOHN CAMPBELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of Nov, 1 coat, value 15s.; 1 handkerchief, 6d.; and 1 pair of gloves, 1s.; the goods of
William Wright.

WILLIAM WRIGHT . I am in the employ of Messrs. Cormack, of New-cross, Deptford. On the 11th of Nov., between eleven and twelve o'clock, my coat, handkerchief, and gloves hung in my master's stable—I saw the prisoner in the yard between one and two, with my coat on his arm—I asked what he did there—he said he wanted the kitchen-door—I asked what he wanted there—he said, "To get a bit of bread—I asked what he did with that coat—he said it was not mine—this is the coat—I am sure it is mine—there was no one but him to take it—the door of the harness-room was open—he was walk
ing about the yard—I followed him some distance, he then gave me the coat, and said, "Let me go this once, I will never do it any more," and that he did it for want.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me in the stable? A. No, you were close to my master's house, and close to the harness-room.
JURY. Q. Did you keep your coat hanging up in the harness-room? A. Yes, on a wooden peg—it was possible for other persons to go into the yard.

GUILTY. Aged 27.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 12TH, 1842.
